This silver casket was presented in 1930 by the provost of the time, Henry Peacock to JM Barrie. 
 
 The casket was presented to commemorate the Freedom Of Kirriemuir and was said at the time to be "The Heart" of Kirrie.

This is a model of how Kirriemuir looked in the 1600's. 
 
 The townhouse display gives a window into the history of Kirriemuir town centre. 
 The building standing in the centre was originally built as a Tolbooth, but since then it's been a Town Jail/Courtroom and also a Chemist before finally serving as a museum to tell the history of the town.

Of the numerous famous men and women associated with Kirriemuir, one stands out as iconic in the music industry. 
 
 Ronald Belford 'Bon' Scott is known worldwide as the lead singer of AC/DC from 1974 until his death in 1980. 
 Scott lived in Kirriemuir until the age of six, moving to Australia with his family and, after performing in several other bands throughout his twenties he replaced lead singer Dave Evans of AC/DC.
 
 AC/DC's popularity grew throughout the 70's eventually reaching the top 20's in the United States with their 1979 album 'Highway to Hell'.
 However, on the evening of 19th February 1980, Scott died after a night out in London. The album 'Back in Black' was released by AC/DC a few months later as a tribute to Scott, becoming the third best-selling album in history. 
 
 Scott is celebrated every year in Kirriemuir during the 'Bonfest' festival hosted by DD8 Music.
